articles.headline: Another Shake-Up at NPR as Chief Steps Down
articles.snippet: The departure of Gary E. Knell was unwelcome news at NPR, which experienced a series of leadership shake-ups before his arrival in 2011.
articles.abstract: The departure of Gary E. Knell was unwelcome news at NPR, which experienced a series of leadership shake-ups before his arrival in 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: NPR, which has suffered a succession of leadership changes over the better part of a decade, needs a new chief executive again.

articles.headline: Business Meetings Move Poolside (Don’t Overdress)
articles.snippet: Cabanas, long a fixture in Beverly Hills and Miami Beach, have become hot hotel amenities in other cities, where they offer a relaxed setting to get a deal done.
articles.abstract: Cabanas, long a fixture in Beverly Hills and Miami Beach, have become hot hotel amenities in other cities, where they offer a relaxed setting to get a deal done.
articles.lead_paragraph: The contract negotiations were progressing well until the woman in the tiny bikini interrupted to ask Mitchell Stevenson and his client if they wanted drinks.

articles.headline: China Takes Aim at Western Ideas
articles.snippet: A document released to Communist Party cadres enumerated what it called subversive social currents, including Western-inspired notions of human rights, that must be fought.
articles.abstract: A document released to Communist Party cadres enumerated what it called subversive social currents, including Western-inspired notions of human rights, that must be fought.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Communist Party cadres have filled meeting halls around China to hear a somber, secretive warning issued by senior leaders. Power could escape their grip, they have been told, unless the party eradicates seven subversive currents coursing through Chinese society.

articles.headline: Falcone to Admit to Wrongdoing as S.E.C. Takes a Harder Line
articles.snippet: The hedge fund manager Phil Falcone has agreed to admit wrongdoing and to be banned from the securities industry for at least five years in a settlement that points to a more aggressive stance by the Securities and Exchange Commission under its ne...
articles.abstract: The hedge fund manager Phil Falcone has agreed to admit wrongdoing and to be banned from the securities industry for at least five years in a settlement that points to a more aggressive stance by the Securities and Exchange Commission under its new chairwoman, Mary Jo White.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s regulator sent a message on Monday that it was now taking a more aggressive stance on securities settlements as it extracted its first admission of wrongdoing under a new policy.

articles.headline: Obama Presses for Action on Bank Rules
articles.snippet: Administration officials and some lawmakers have expressed frustration that critical parts of President Obama’s financial overhaul, the Dodd-Frank act, remain unenforced.
articles.abstract: Administration officials and some lawmakers have expressed frustration that critical parts of President Obama’s financial overhaul, the Dodd-Frank act, remain unenforced.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama urged the nation’s top financial regulators on Monday to move faster on new rules for Wall Street, telling them in a private White House meeting that they must work to prevent a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Hiring the Well-Connected Isn’t Always a Scandal
articles.snippet: Several companies have explicit policies against cronyism, and hiring a family member simply for a relationship can be troubling and may not necessarily serve a company’s interests. But that doesn’t mean the children of powerful people aren’t alwa...
articles.abstract: Several companies have explicit policies against cronyism, and hiring a family member simply for a relationship can be troubling and may not necessarily serve a company’s interests. But that doesn’t mean the children of powerful people aren’t always qualified candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: When is a new hire on Wall Street scrutinized over possible bribery?

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia Promises to Aid Egypt’s Regime
articles.snippet: As Europeans and the United States considered cutting cash aid to Egypt, Saudi Arabia said that it and its allies would make up any reduction and vowed continued support.
articles.abstract: As Europeans and the United States considered cutting cash aid to Egypt, Saudi Arabia said that it and its allies would make up any reduction and vowed continued support.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Saudi Arabia has emerged as the foremost supporter of Egypt’s military rulers, explicitly backing the violent crackdown on Islamists and using its oil wealth and diplomatic muscle to help defy growing pressure from the West to end the bloodshed in search of a political solution.

articles.headline: Scandal-Weary San Diego Asks a Question: Where’s the Mayor?
articles.snippet: Bob Filner was supposed to be back on the job after two weeks in rehab and a week of personal leave, but at City Hall he was nowhere to be found.
articles.abstract: Bob Filner was supposed to be back on the job after two weeks in rehab and a week of personal leave, but at City Hall he was nowhere to be found.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — In the five weeks since Mayor Bob Filner was first accused of sexual harassment by an aide, San Diego has almost felt like a city held hostage.
articles.byline: By Rob Davis and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: ‘Today’ Is Starting Oprah-like Book Club
articles.snippet: The NBC morning show will promote a book every four or five weeks, starting on Tuesday with “The Bone Season,” by Samantha Shannon.
articles.abstract: The NBC morning show will promote a book every four or five weeks, starting on Tuesday with “The Bone Season,” by Samantha Shannon.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Today” will introduce a new monthly book club on Tuesday, a happy development for a publishing industry frustrated by years of shrinking television time devoted to authors.

articles.headline: An Egypt Arrest, and a Brotherhood on the Run
articles.snippet: Mohamed Badie was arrested hours after a court ordered the release of former President Hosni Mubarak, offering a measure of Egypt’s redrawn political landscape.
articles.abstract: Mohamed Badie was arrested hours after a court ordered the release of former President Hosni Mubarak, offering a measure of Egypt’s redrawn political landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s authoritarian government has harassed and repressed the Muslim Brotherhood for most of its existence. But for the last three decades the authorities stopped short of touching the group’s revered leader, the supreme guide, who oversaw the country’s most effective social, political and religious organization despite its outlawed status.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Mayy El Sheikh

articles.headline: Health Care Costs Climb Moderately, Survey Says
articles.snippet: The average annual premium for a family rose 4 percent this year and 5 percent for individuals.
articles.abstract: The average annual premium for a family rose 4 percent this year and 5 percent for individuals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Premiums for employer-provided health insurance have increased by relatively modest amounts this year, according to a new survey, a further sign that once-torrid health care inflation has abated for now.
